headline: Why Dollar Tree (DLTR) Stock Is Trading Lower Today
summary: Shares of discount treasure-hunt retailer Dollar Tree (NASDAQ:DLTR) fell 7% in the afternoon session after investors appeared to look past the company's second-quarter earnings beat and raised full-year guidance, focusing instead on concerning underlying trends. The discount retailer reported second-quarter revenue and adjusted earnings that topped Wall Street's expectations and lifted its full-year outlook for both metrics. However, the positive headline numbers were overshadowed by a steep 38.

headline: Dollar Tree Raises Outlook But Tariff Pressures Spark Investor Selloff
summary: Dollar Tree Inc. (NASDAQ:DLTR) shares fell on Wednesday after the discount retailer posted stronger-than-expected second-quarter sales and earnings, as margin pressures from tariffs and a cautious profit outlook tempered investor sentiment. The discount retailer’s second-quarter sales increased 12.3% to $4.567 billion, beating the consensus of $4.484 billion. headline: These Stocks Are Moving the Most Today: Alphabet, Apple, Zscaler, Nvidia, Figma, and More
summary: Alphabet  jumped 5.8% after a judge in the U.S. vs. Google antitrust case ruled the search giant wouldn’t have to sell its Chrome web browser.  U.S. District Judge Amit Mehta ruled, however, that Google would no longer be permitted to enter or keep any exclusive contracts that relate to distribution of Google Search, Chrome, Google Assistant, and the Gemini app.  The judge also ordered Google to share search data with its competitors.

headline: Dollar Tree Posts Better-Than-Expected Earnings. Why the Stock Is Falling.
summary: Dollar Tree  posted an earnings beat and strong results for the fiscal second quarter, but the stock was falling following an underwhelming third-quarter forecast.  Adjusted earnings in the second quarter of 77 cents a share topped the consensus estimate of 42 cents.  Dollar Tree  hiked its fiscal-year net sales guidance to a range of $19.3 billion to $19.5 billion, up from $18.5 billion to $19.1 billion.

raw.headline: Dollar Tree Posts Better-Than-Expected Earnings. Why the Stock Is Falling.
raw.summary: Dollar Tree  posted an earnings beat and strong results for the fiscal second quarter, but the stock was falling following an underwhelming third-quarter forecast.  Adjusted earnings in the second quarter of 77 cents a share topped the consensus estimate of 42 cents.  Dollar Tree  hiked its fiscal-year net sales guidance to a range of $19.3 billion to $19.5 billion, up from $18.5 billion to $19.1 billion.

headline: Dollar Tree (NASDAQ:DLTR) Beats Q2 Sales Expectations, Full-Year Outlook Slightly Exceeds Expectations
summary: Discount treasure-hunt retailer Dollar Tree (NASDAQ:DLTR) reported Q2 CY2025 results beating Wall Street’s revenue expectations, but sales fell by 38.1% year on year to $4.57 billion. The company’s full-year revenue guidance of $19.4 billion at the midpoint came in 1.3% above analysts’ estimates. Its non-GAAP profit of $0.77 per share was 87.6% above analysts’ consensus estimates.

raw.headline: Dollar Tree (NASDAQ:DLTR) Beats Q2 Sales Expectations, Full-Year Outlook Slightly Exceeds Expectations
raw.summary: Discount treasure-hunt retailer Dollar Tree (NASDAQ:DLTR) reported Q2 CY2025 results beating Wall Street’s revenue expectations, but sales fell by 38.1% year on year to $4.57 billion. The company’s full-year revenue guidance of $19.4 billion at the midpoint came in 1.3% above analysts’ estimates. Its non-GAAP profit of $0.77 per share was 87.6% above analysts’ consensus estimates.

headline: Dollar Tree raises annual targets on steady demand for cheaper goods
summary: Dollar Tree's shares, which have jumped about 50% this year, were down about 5% before the bell after the company said its current-quarter profit would be largely flat sequentially due to a hit from tariffs.  U.S. President Donald Trump's import tariffs have squeezed margins for retailers who are looking to keep prices low for value-seeking consumers, amplifying challenges for businesses navigating increased uncertainty and sticky inflation in a fragile economic environment.  Dollar Tree's cost of sales rose to nearly $3 billion in the quarter, from $2.67 billion a year ago, due to tariffs and higher discounts on some items.

raw.headline: Dollar Tree raises annual targets on steady demand for cheaper goods

Dollar Tree's cost of sales rose to nearly $3 billion in the quarter, from $2.67 billion a year ago, due to tariffs and higher discounts on some items.

headline: Stock market today: Nasdaq, S&P 500 futures rise after Google spared in antitrust ruling, with jobs data ahead
summary: US stock futures mostly rose after a ruling in a landmark antitrust case refrained from forcing Google to sell its Chrome browser but instituted other requirements that could shake the tech giant's hold on search.

headline: Salesforce earnings, JOLTS data, Fed comments: What to Watch
summary: Market Domination Overtime host Josh Lipton takes a look at the top stories for investors to watch on Wednesday, Sept. 3. Dollar Tree (DLTR), Campbell's (CPB), and Macy's (M) report quarterly earnings results in the morning. In the afternoon, Salesforce (CRM), Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE), and American Eagle Outfitters (AEO) will announce earnings. In the morning, the US Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) will post the Job Openings and Labor Turnover Survey (JOLTS) data for July. Economists expect the number of job openings to drop to 7.37 million from June's 7.44 million. St. Louis Federal Reserve President Alberto Musalem is delivering remarks in the morning, and Minneapolis Fed President Neel Kashkari will speak in the afternoon. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Market Domination Overtime.
